title: Battles
content: A game of Veilrot is played on a 3' x 3' battlefield, a shattered stretch of blighted earth filled with ruin, growth, and the remnants of forgotten wars. Before blades are drawn and relics claimed, players must first shape the stage of conflict—defining the terrain, deployment, and purpose of the battle to come. This setup phase lays the foundation for every tactical decision and bloody exchange that follows, and is completed through the following steps:

sections.title: Set Up Battlefield Terrain
sections.content: Players collaboratively place terrain features across the board to create a rich and tactical battlefield. Terrain influences movement, line of sight, and cover. (A full terrain system will be defined later, including types, effects, and density.)

sections.title: Define Starting Zones
sections.content: Once the battlefield has been set, it's time to determine where each warband will enter the fray. Starting zones dictate how your models enter the board, shape early positioning, and heavily influence tactical momentum. In Veilrot, there are two broad types of deployment scenarios: Pitched Skirmishes and Asymmetrical Engagements.

sections.title: Determine Deployment Type
sections.content:
At the beginning of this step, roll a single six-sided die (D6):
  • On a result of 1–4, the mission is a Pitched Skirmish.
  • On a result of 5–6, it becomes an Asymmetrical Engagement.
This single roll sets the tone of the battle—whether both forces arrive on equal footing or whether the confrontation is more fractured and uneven.

sections.title: Pitched Skirmish
sections.content:
In a Pitched Skirmish, both warbands approach the battlefield on equal terms. Roll 1D6 and consult the Deployment Zone Table. The result determines which deployment layout is used for both players.
Each player will then deploy their entire warband within the same deployment layout on opposite sides of the board, following the mirrored setup shown on the diagram associated with the result.
This method promotes fair positioning and direct conflict, ideal for balanced missions or ritualistic engagements between equally matched enemies.

sections.title: Asymmetrical Engagement
sections.content:
In an Asymmetrical Engagement, the battlefield is fractured and uncertain. Each player rolls 1D6 separately, and determines their own deployment zone based on the Deployment Zone Table.
One warband might arrive in a tight central cluster, while the other appears along flanking paths or spread across distant corners. This creates chaotic openings, encourages risk-taking, and reflects the unpredictable, fragmented nature of war in the Veilrot wastes.

sections.title: Establish Mission Rules
sections.content: With the battlefield and deployment zones established, it's time to determine what your warbands are fighting over. This stage defines the heart of the scenario—what must be claimed, protected, or destroyed to achieve victory.

sections.title: Mission Rules
sections.content:
Each battle in Veilrot is driven by the mission at hand. A mission defines the rules of engagement, scoring conditions, and special mechanics that will shape your warband's path to victory. No two missions play quite the same, and mastering a variety of objectives is crucial to long-term success.

Choosing a Mission
Before the battle begins, the mission must be chosen. The mission defines the objectives, the scoring conditions, and the strange or brutal logic that shapes the conflict. In Veilrot, missions are grouped into three broad categories, each with its own tone and tactical demands.
To determine which kind of mission will be played:
One player rolls 1D6 to select a mission category:
  • 1–2: Seize the Field — Focused on control and presence.
  • 3–4: Twist the Thread — Interactive and action-based objectives.
  • 5–6: Endure the Ruin — Hazardous or alternate scoring conditions.
Once a category is determined, roll 1D6 again to select a mission from that group.
Alternatively, for narrative play, players may choose a mission directly from any category.

Domination through presence. These missions reward positioning, pressure, and sustained control.

Manipulation and deception. These missions reward tactical flexibility and misdirection.

Resilience and recovery. These missions reward survival and resource management.

sections.title: Player Objectives
sections.content:
After the mission is selected but before deployment, each player rolls 1D6:
  • On a 1–3, roll on Table A: Tactical Objectives.
  • On a 4–6, roll on Table B: Strike Objectives.
Then roll 1D6 again to determine your objective from the chosen table.
Keep the result secret until it is completed or revealed at the end of the game.
You may only complete one Player Objective per battle. Each one has its own listed Victory Point reward.

1. Line Breaker — 3 Victory Point
Control three different objectives in the same round.
Success requires timing and bold positioning to claim multiple zones at once.

2. Zone Denial — 3 Victory Points
Control three different objectives at the end of the game.
This long-term goal rewards strategic resilience and endgame control.

3. Sigil Claimant — 3 Victory Point
Perform the Claim Sigil action on an objective. This Player Objective can be achieved more than once, but only once for each objective on the battlefield.
This action represents your warband marking an objective site for unknown purposes.
Claim Sigil (Action): While controlling an objective, a model may perform this action on an objective they are contesting.

4. Hold the Line — 3 Victory Point
At the end of the game, at least half of your starting models must remain alive on the battlefield.
Simple, but challenging in brutal scenarios.

5. Oppressive Advance — 3 Victory Point
At any point during the game, have at least one model contesting every Primary Objective.
You don't need to control them—just be within 1".

6. Commanding Presence — 3 Victory Point
Have your Leader contest a controlled Primary Objective at the end of any round.
Assert dominance through leadership and placement.
1. Wipe the Blade — 3 Victory Point
Destroy four enemy figures during the game.
A steady and relentless approach to battlefield elimination.

2. Break the Chain — 3 Victory Points
Destroy the enemy Leader model.
High risk, high reward—requires precise execution or raw power.

3. Precision Execution — 3 Victory Points
Destroy two enemy figures while also scoring at least one critical hit.
You must deliver the killing blow in an attack that includes at least one 6 on the Hit roll.

4. First to Spill — 3 Victory Point
Be the first player to destroy an enemy figure.
If your opponent scores the first kill, this objective cannot be completed.

5. No Witnesses — 3 Victory Points
At the end of the game, no enemy figures may be within 6" of your deployment zone.
Defend your territory and deny your opponent infiltration.

6. Strike and Fade — 3 Victory Points
In a single round, destroy an enemy figure and then move the attacker 5" or more away from the site of the kill.
Mobility and precision define this surgical goal.

sections.title: Narrative Layer (Optional)
sections.content:
Every battlefield in Veilrot tells a story. Some whisper in fungal breath, others scream with silver flame or machine static. While the mission defines how victory is measured, the narrative layer defines what the battle feels like—and what's truly at stake.

Using a Narrative Layer
Before defining the mission and battlefield, players may choose to add a Narrative Layer to their battle. This step is entirely optional and doesn't affect gameplay rules, but it provides rich flavor, deeper immersion, and inspiration for terrain, model behavior, and storytelling. It can also help with visualizing and encapsulating the setting around the conflict.
To generate one randomly:
Roll 1D6 to determine which category of battlefield you're fighting on.

Narrative Layer Categories
1–2: Sacred & Profaned Sites
3–4: Corruption & Collapse
5–6: Industrial & Technolithic Wreckage

Then roll 1D6 again on the chosen table to determine the specific location and its flavor.
Alternatively, players can choose a narrative layer that suits their factions, models, or terrain setup.
Narrative Layers do not alter rules or objectives unless agreed upon by both players. They are purely atmospheric—but often influence how players interpret events or roleplay their figures.

These are battlegrounds of belief—hallowed ruins, cursed shrines, and relic-laced soil that still echoes with faith, fear, or fury.

Once a fungal reliquary. Now a breathing ruin. Primary Objectives are pulsing crypt-pods, sealed in sporelight. Secondary markers are communion points or rotted altars. Everything here lives—some of it doesn't want to.
An old site of devotion to the shattered moon, scattered with prayer-flags and charred votive pits. Objectives are memory-altars. Every faction claims it once belonged to them.
A martyred body's vertebrae arches from the ground like a cathedral. Primary Objectives are bone-altars. Secondary are nerve-beacons or organ shrines. Even the wind sounds like whispering prayers.
Once a Moonfall chapel, now burned and hollow. Objectives lie among charred pillars and scorched censers. Faith lingers in the ash—but so does something else.
A divine fragment impacted here generations ago. Lunar shards pulse underfoot. The battlefield is cratered and humming. Objectives are still warm.
An old archive-keep defiled by scavengers. Objectives are shattered data-vaults and bleeding obelisks. Rot and reverence mix in the dust.
These sites are saturated with Bloom, rot, or broken memory. They shift, breathe, and devour. Battlefields that refuse to stay dead.

Fissures in the ground vent Bloomlight and fungal spores. Objectives are rupture points. The land groans. Sometimes, it answers.
Trenchworks drowned in rot and silence. Objectives lie half-submerged in waterlogged soil. Footing is treacherous. So is memory.
The corpse of a crashed relic-engine spills sanctified tissue into the ground. Primary Objectives are graft-pods. The smell of sacred oil and wet iron never fades.
A site soaked in centuries of blood. Nothing grows. Objectives are grave-posts and marrow shrines. Even the rain feels hostile.
Once a fortified keep, now drowned in moss and regret. Objectives lie sunken and half-forgotten. The trees hum with old warnings.
A twisted grove, blooming with impossible fruit. Objectives hang from crooked trees and fruit-stained altars. Every root remembers joy—and mocks it.
Remnants of the machine cults and shattered sciences that once tried to bind the world. These sites thrum with static, timing, and rusted memory.

A Verdigrave caravan lost mid-transfer. Objectives are fallen crates, ritual rigs, and lockboxes. Looters come like flies. So do worse things.
An Orrery telemetry tower flickers back to life. Objectives are signal pylons and power anchors. The battlefield is shaped by fractured grids and angular ruin.
A border-watching outpost, once aglow with moonfire. Objectives are beacon towers and oathstones. Some say relighting the lanterns will draw divine attention. Not all believe it's worth the risk.
Invisible strands of filament rise from beneath the dirt. Objectives are magnetic pylons and data-nodes. The land sings in codes no one remembers how to read.
A shattered canyon where sound fractures and dies. Objectives are resonant spires. Speech here is wrong. Orders echo back rewritten.
A dried-out fungal dredging field, abandoned after the Gloam Exodus. Objectives are dredge sieves and rusted pumps. The air is dusty with rot. Nothing has grown right here since.

sections.title: Place Objective Markers
sections.content:
Objective markers represent relics, control points, corrupted growths, or sites of tactical value. These can influence the flow of battle dramatically, creating focal points that demand attention and draw blood.
To determine how many objective markers are placed and where they are located, roll 1D6 and consult the Objective Marker Table. This roll determines the type and layout of objectives for the scenario. Some results may create a single focal point; others may scatter multiple smaller objectives across the board.
This method ensures that each game feels different, with terrain, deployment, and objectives combining in unique ways to shape the strategies both players will need to adopt.

NameDescriptionSetupImage


Once you have your result, place the objective markers as described—usually at set distances from the center or corners of the board. Be sure to place them before any models are deployed.
After objective markers are placed, players can then determine the mission's Primary Objective and any Secondary Objectives that will be in play. These objectives define how players earn points or claim victory and are influenced by the positioning of the markers already on the board.

sections.title: Mission Example
sections.content:
To better understand how Veilrot battles are assembled, here's an example of how two players generate a full mission using all the core setup steps.

Step 1: Add a Narrative Layer (Optional)
To immerse the battlefield in Veilrot's world, the players choose to add a narrative flavor.
They roll 1D6 to determine the category: 2 → "Sacred & Profaned Sites"
Then they roll 1D6 again: 5, resulting in "Cracked Halo"
"Once, something divine landed here. Now it only smolders and draws scavengers."
Objectives are lunar core fragments and relic shards. The terrain becomes cratered, warped by memory-heat and divine fallout.

Step 2: Set Up the Battlefield
The players agree to use a 3' × 3' board. They populate it with ruins, fungal clusters, barricades, and elevation features, ensuring varied terrain that offers line of sight breaks, cover, and movement challenges.

Step 3: Define Deployment Zones
One player rolls 1D6: the result is a 3. This means the game will be a "Pitched Skirmish" and both players use the mirrored deployment zone. They roll another D6: the result is a 4: "Encroaching Tide" deployment zone from the deployment zones table. Both players place their warbands in two rectangular boxes by their right table corner.

Step 4: Determine the Mission Rules
A player rolls 1D6 to determine the mission type. The result is a 5, which falls into the "Endure the Ruin" category (Hazard missions).
They roll another 1D6 to select a mission from that group: 4, resulting in the mission "Volatile Ground."
They consult the mission sheet:
Primary Objectives score points as normal.
Secondary Objectives erupt when contested for the first time, causing damage.
The mission emphasizes movement and zone denial.

Step 5: Place Objective Markers
The players roll 1D6 on the Objective Marker Layout Table and get a 2, resulting in the "Tri-Line" setup—three objectives placed in a horizontal line across the center of the battlefield.
Two of these are designated as Primary, and one as Secondary, based on the mission instructions.

Step 6: Determine Player Objectives
Each player secretly rolls for a Player Objective.
Player A rolls 3 then 2, landing on "Zone Denial" from the Tactical table: Control three different objectives at the end of the game (2 VP).
Player B rolls 6 then 1, landing on "Wipe the Blade" from the Strike table: Destroy three enemy figures over the course of the game (1 VP).
These are kept hidden until fulfilled or revealed at the end of the battle.
The mission is now fully formed. The players begin deploying their figures and preparing for the first round of battle.
